Toby, your shedding is still in waves and you haven’t yet seen regrowth fuzz. That suggests you’re hovering in the peak/stabilization border. Because your main triggers (chronic illness + med change + high stress) are still ongoing, your body is extra sensitive to cortisol swings. Locking down a fixed sleep schedule is the single “big domino” that steadies cortisol, shortens lag, and moves you toward a true stabilization so regrowth can finally switch on. 🌙

What to do

  • Pick one target bedtime and keep it within ±30 min every night—including weekends.
  • Wake up at the same time daily, even if sleep felt restless.
  • Expose your eyes to morning light within 30–60 min of waking.
  • Keep your last meal at least 90 min before bed to ease digestion and deeper sleep.

Your recommended schedule

  • Bedtime: 11:00 pm (lights out no later than 11:30).
  • Wake time: 7:00 am sharp.
  • Wind‑down start: 10:15 pm (screens dim, calming ritual).
  • Morning anchor: light exposure + protein‑rich breakfast for cortisol reset.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set an evening alarm at 10:15 pm to begin wind‑down (stretch, tea, journaling to ease rumination).
  2. Cut screen brightness and silence notifications by 10:30.
  3. Place caffeine strictly before 2 pm (you already do this, just keep consistent).
  4. Shift your last meal earlier—aim 1.5–2 hrs pre‑bed instead of right before sleep.
  5. Morning: get 5–10 min daylight at a window or walk, even if cloudy.
  6. If stress spikes at night, keep a notepad by your bed: jot, close book, release until morning.

Why this works (for you)

  • Because your stress and thyroid illness are ongoing, a fixed circadian anchor flattens cortisol spikes that push hairs into telogen.
  • Your shedding waves suggest overlapping triggers from Feb–May; this practice shortens lag so stabilization locks in sooner.
  • Protein/iron intake is low—steady sleep improves hormonal tone (thyroid, progesterone) so nutrients you do eat can channel into follicles rather than stress defense.
  • Regular timing reduces PMS flares and anxiety rumination at night, both of which amplify shedding pressure.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Staying up past midnight on weekends → resets your cortisol clock; if it happens, get back on track the next night without guilt.
  • Green lights: Within 7–10 days, earlier sleepiness at 10:30; smoother mornings without a “stress jolt”; slightly smaller shedding waves by week two.
  • Remember, you don’t need perfection—just consistent anchors. Every regular night stacks toward regrowth. ❤️
